I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the establishment of 
the Platform for Climate Resilient and Low Carbon Urban Development through research and 
development at the Asian Development Bank (ADB) headquarters and in selected partner cities 
in ADB developing member countries (DMCs). The platform will be administered from Manila and 
allow ADB and key DMC stakeholders to share knowledge related to climate-informed urban 
development. 
 
2.  The TA will support the urban development-related priorities of ADB’s Climate Change 
Operational Framework, 2017–2030 (CCOF2030).1 The TA will support selected ADB DMCs to 
develop  nationally  determined  contributions  (NDCs).2  The  TA  will  also  facilitate  city-level 
investments in climate-resilient, low-carbon projects.3 
 
3.  The  TA  supports  the  priorities  articulated  in  ADB’s  Strategy  2030,  particularly  the 
operational priority on tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and 
enhancing environmental sustainability; the operational priority of making cities more livable, and 
the operational priority on fostering regional cooperation and integration.4 The TA also supports 
the use of high-level technology in projects.5 Climate-resilient and low-carbon urban development 
is also an integral part of ADB’s drive under Strategy 2030 to make cities more livable. The TA is 
included in the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department’s 2019 results-based 
work plan, supports the ADB Urban Operational Plan, 2012–2020, and aligns with the ADB 
Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020.6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Cities are home to more than 50% of the global population and consume more than two-
thirds of the world’s energy, which accounts for 70% of global greenhouse gas emissions.7 With 
90% of the world’s urban areas situated on coastlines, cities are particularly vulnerable to climate 
change impacts such as rising sea levels, severe heat waves, intensifying storms and floods, and 
prolonged droughts. These impacts cause loss of life, social disruption, and economic hardship 
among vulnerable urban populations. National urban policies must be bold in prioritizing climate-
resilient, low-carbon development to mitigate these impacts. 
 
5.  To increase awareness and mobilize finance needed to bring these commitments to 
traction,  policy  makers,  the  private  sector,  and  investors  must  work  together  to  prioritize 
sustainable urban development and investment models. This will require ambitious national 
                                                
1  ADB. 2017. Climate Change Operational Framework, 2017–2030: Enhanced Actions for Low Greenhouse Gas 
Emissions and Climate-Resilient Development. Manila. 
2  NDCs outline countries’ commitments to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and their climate adaptation priorities. 
As of May 2019, 40 of 41 DMCs receiving ADB financing support have ratified the Paris Agreement on climate 
change. The Kyrgyz Republic is the only ADB DMC that has not ratified the Paris Agreement. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 7 December 2018. 
4  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila.  
5  ADB. 2016. Use of High-Level Technology in Projects. Memorandum. 21 April (internal). 
6  ADB. 2013. Urban Operational Plan 2012–2020. Manila; and ADB. 2016. Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation 
and Integration, 2016–2020: Promoting connectivity, competitiveness, regional public goods, and collective action 
for Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
7  The New Climate Economy. 2018. Unlocking the Inclusive Growth Story of the 21st Century: Accelerating Climate 
Action in Urgent Times. Washington, DC.

2 
climate actions, which should be reflected in the NDCs of DMCs.8 In their current form, NDCs 
reflect a lack of public financial resources, weak financial and institutional systems, and limited 
knowledge  and  awareness  to  support  effective  climate-resilient  and  low-carbon  urban 
development. Concrete guidelines are needed to help DMCs draft NDCs that will support the 
development of more sustainable, resilient, and livable cities.9 
 
6.  The CCOF2030 calls for a “Spotlight on Cities” to develop analytical tools that will assist 
DMCs with (i) the collection of critical information on greenhouse gas emissions and data to 
support risk indexes, energy use, and projections for major cities (including city-based industries) 
across the region; (ii) the establishment of a catalog of rapidly growing small- and medium-sized 
cities to promote green growth and climate-smart principles from the ground up, with a focus on 
vulnerable segments; and (iii) the development and implementation of a multisector model for 
sustainable urban development that strengthens climate resilience and supports a transition to a 
low-carbon-emitting economy, while meeting urban infrastructure and urban service needs.10 
 
7.  Making cities more resilient and livable is also a goal of ADB’s Strategy 2030. Two 
priorities of the Strategy 2030 are aligned with the CCOF2030: (i) the focus on resilient cities, 
providing strategic physical, social, and institutional infrastructure that enhances resilience to 
climate change and disasters; and (ii) the priority on green cities with infrastructure that enables 
resource efficiency and healthy lifestyles. 
 
8.  Against this backdrop, the Climate Change and Disaster Risk Management Thematic 
Group and the Urban Sector Group of ADB have developed a joint core rationale for the TA: (i) 
centralized planning of NDCs does not capture climate risk-informed urban development; and (ii) 
cities do not prioritize climate-informed, multisector investments and, as a consequence, DMCs 
lack capacity to integrate climate-resilient, low-carbon urban development objectives in their 
NDCs. This TA project will address these disconnects by fostering low-carbon planning and 
devising climate and disaster-risk-management assessments that result in a faster transition to 
climate-resilient urban development planning in DMCs. 
 
9.  The TA is envisioned as a platform that will foster knowledge exchange among DMCs, 
development partners, and the private sector. The initiative will be operational from 2019 to 
2022.11  The  platform’s  outputs  will  be  developed  in  cooperation  with  (i)  selected  DMC 
governments; (ii) selected city governments; (iii) ADB teams working on urban development 
across operational departments; (iv) ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department; and (v) an 
extensive network of development partners, technical organizations, academia, the private sector, 
                                                
8  Climate Action Tracker. The Climate Action Tracker estimates that the planned contribution of most NDCs is not in 
line with efforts to meet the Paris Agreement’s long-term goal to limit global warming this century to 2°C while aiming 
to limit the temperature increase even further to 1.5°C. 
9  T. Day et.al. 2017. Sectoral Implementation of Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs). Briefing Series. Bonn: 
Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ). 
10 This TA targets small- and medium-sized cities. City size measured by total population will vary by region, but the 
TA will not include the megalopolises of the People’s Republic of China or India, nor will it exclude the smaller coastal 
cities of Pacific DMCs. Where relevant, the analysis will include climate-change-related cross-border risks for 
urban corridors. 
11 The CCOF2030 consists of two operational phases. Phase 1 (2017–2023) supports the scaling up of climate change 
investments in line with ADB’s $6 billion climate financing commitment by 2020. Phase 2 (2024–2030) will position 
ADB to further scale up its assistance taking account lessons learned in phase 1. ADB will harmonize phase 2 actions 
with the second generation of NDCs and DMCs’ increasingly ambitious climate actions. For this TA, funding is 
secured until 2022. Additional financing will be sought to expand coverage.

3 
and civil society organizations. ADB will initially establish the platform via the four outputs of this 
TA. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impacts and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: (i) cities’ vulnerability to catastrophic climate 
events reduced and (ii) cities’ carbon emissions and air pollution levels decreased (footnote 1). 
The TA will have the following outcome: DMCs’ capacity to integrate climate-resilient, low-carbon 
urban development objectives in NDCs improved.12 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  Output  1:  ADB  practice  on  urban  climate  resilience  and  low-carbon  planning 
documented. A scoping exercise will be conducted over 6 months to consolidate findings from 
ADB-wide TA and lending projects on urban development, climate change, and disaster risk 
management. During the scoping period, two DMC cities under two distinct ADB operations 
departments will be selected. The selection criteria will include (i) the target city’s readiness to 
undertake the foreseen TA activities, (ii) evidence of potential synergies with ongoing TA or 
lending projects in the target city, and (iii) eligibility of the target city under the Urban Climate 
Change Resilience Trust Fund (UCCRTF) under the Urban Financing Partnership Facility.13 
Additional funds will be sought later to expand the geographic scope of the TA and leverage the 
concept beyond countries for which the UCCRTF can provide funding.14 A cross-sector and cross-
thematic coordination structure will be established during scoping to enrich the platform with 
perspectives from different sectors and themes beyond urban development and climate change 
and disaster risk management. 
 
12.  Output 2: Knowledge of governance and institutional support for urban climate 
resilience  and  low-carbon  development  improved.  Improved  governance  and  public 
engagement are critical foundations of a shift toward climate-resilient urban development and 
sustainable infrastructure service delivery in cities. In the selected target cities, this output will 
identify policy recommendations and financing plans to support actionable NDCs that can lead to 
low-carbon and climate-resilient urban investments. Activities under this output will lead to the 
formulation of recommendations for national, regional, and city-level actions. Effective national 
urban  policy  actions  include  maximizing  public  fiscal  capacity  and  creating  incentives  for 
sustainable urban development; apportioning revenue collection and borrowing responsibilities 
and  allocating  revenue  across  different  jurisdictions  (including  city  governments);  and 
implementing comprehensive, climate-smart national urban policies, including platforms and 
partnerships to finance the deficit in sustainable infrastructure in urban areas.15 
 
13.  Output 3: Knowledge on access to finance, and climate resilience and low-carbon 
planning improved. This output will (i) strengthen the capacity of local stakeholders in selected 
target cities to tap financing for strengthening climate resilience, (ii) develop integrated climate 
                                                
12 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
13 Financing partners of the UCCRTF: the Rockefeller Foundation and the governments of Switzerland and the 
United Kingdom. 
14 A change in scope for the TA will be proposed when additional funding has been identified. The eligible counties to 
receive support from the fund are Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan, the Philippines, and 
Viet Nam. 
15 ADB. 2013. Urban Operational Plan 2012–2020. Manila.

4 
risk management approaches, and (iii) develop bottom-up models of low-carbon and/or climate 
action plans. In contrast to output 2, which covers national priorities, this output will recommend 
actions to be implemented at the city level. Public finance has traditionally been a significant 
source of urban infrastructure investment, but public budgets are often insufficient for larger or 
more complex projects, and the financing gap is most evident in cities in low- and middle-income 
countries. Cities need support to develop pipelines of well-prepared and bankable investments to 
enhance  urban  resilience;  they  also  need  assistance  in  improving  access  for  private  and 
institutional investors and facilitating strategic investments to build resilience.16 Output 3 will 
explore specific resilience-building investment prioritization methodologies to protect the urban 
poor and populations that are more vulnerable to climate change. The urban poor are highly 
exposed to shocks and stresses triggered by natural hazards and climate change, which result in 
loss of life, damage to assets, disruptions of livelihoods, and loss of income. These impacts extend 
to local governments, which suffer increased socioeconomic burden to provide post-disaster 
relief. In the selected target cities, this output will explore methodologies to build investment road 
maps for low-carbon urban development. 
 
14.  Output  4:  Knowledge  sharing  and  city  partnerships  enhanced.  This  output  will 
support the target cities to identify and address their knowledge gaps and requirements, in order 
to develop an information base for risk-informed decision-making. The output will assist cities in 
leveraging partnerships to build capacity for resilient and low-carbon urban development. Output 
4 will also develop best practice knowledge products to support climate change appraisal in urban 
investment projects. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
UCCRTF under the Urban Financing Partnership Facility and administered by ADB. The key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. Additional financing will be identified to expand TA 
coverage beyond UCCRTF eligible countries. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA and will be the executing agency. The Climate Change and 
Disaster Risk Management Division under the Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
Department will lead overall implementation and will coordinate closely with the Urban Sector 
Group  and  relevant  ADB  operations  departments,  including  the  Private  Sector  Operations 
Department. Knowledge products developed under the TA will be disseminated through the ADB 
website. The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                
16 The output will address strategies to mobilize private finance for NDC implementation at the city level, particularly (i) 
mobilizing private sector finance in infrastructure, (ii) creating private financing options for adaptation measures, and 
(iii) climate proofing private investments and developing risk-management schemes.

The TA will engage 20 person-months of international inputs (i.e., climate finance specialists, 
urban planning and development specialist, climate change economist); and 42 person-months 
of national inputs (senior project coordination specialists, urban climate change specialists, 
workshop coordinators). ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions, using the individual consultant selection method or framework agreements, as 
necessary.17 Selected reports will be published as knowledge products in English and the local 
language, as needed, with limited print copies prepared and disseminated to training and/or 
workshop participants from DMCs and development partners. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$1,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Urban Climate Change Resilience Trust Fund 
under the Urban Financing Partnership Facility for Establishing a Platform for Climate-Resilient 
and Low-Carbon Urban Development and hereby reports this action to the Board.
